attributes.name: Body
attributes.description:
Renders a <tbody> element and yields the row component, row data and index.

<table.body as |body person index|>
  <body.row as |row|>
    <row.cell>
      {{person.firstName}} #{{index}}
    </row.cell>
    <row.cell>
      {{person.lastName}}
    </row.cell>
    <row.cell>
      {{person.points}}
    </row.cell>
  </body.row>
</table.body>

It can also be used as a blockless component to let yeti table automatically unroll thee rows for you, based on the @prop arguments you passed in to the column definition components.

<table.body/>

Remember that this component's block will be rendered once per each item in the @data array.

arguments.name: rowClass
arguments.description: Adds a class to each <tr> element. Can be used with both the blockless and block invocations.

arguments.name: onRowClick
arguments.description: Adds a click action to each row, called with the clicked row's data as an argument. Can be used with both the blockless and block invocations.

attributes.name: Cell
attributes.description:
Renders a <td> element (if its corresponding column definition has @visible={{true}}).

<row.cell>
  {{person.firstName}}
</row.cell>

attributes.name: Row
attributes.description:
Renders a <tr> element and yields the cell component.

<body.row as |row|>
  <row.cell>
    {{person.firstName}} #{{index}}
  </row.cell>
  <row.cell>
    {{person.lastName}}
  </row.cell>
  <row.cell>
    {{person.points}}
  </row.cell>
</body.row>

Remember you can cutomize each <tr> class or @onClick handler based on the row data because you have access to it from the body component.

<table.body as |body person|>
  <body.row class={{if person.isInvalid "error"}} as |row|>
    <row.cell>
      {{person.firstName}}
    </row.cell>
    <row.cell>
      {{person.lastName}}
    </row.cell>
    <row.cell>
      {{person.points}}
    </row.cell>
  </body.row>
</table.body>

arguments.name: onClick
arguments.description: Adds a click action to the row.

attributes.name: YetiTable
attributes.description:
The primary Yeti Table component. This component represents the root of the table, and manages high level state of all of its subcomponents.

<YetiTable @data={{data}} as |table|>

  <table.header as |header|>
    <header.column @prop="firstName">
      First name
    </header.column>
    <header.column @prop="lastName">
      Last name
    </header.column>
    <header.column @prop="points">
      Points
    </header.column>
  </table.header>

  <table.body/>

</YetiTable>

arguments.name: data
arguments.description: The data for Yeti Table to render. It can be an array or a promise that resolves with an array. The only case when @data is optional is if a @loadData was passed in.

arguments.name: loadData
arguments.description:
The function that will be called when Yeti Table needs data. This argument is used when you don't have all the data available or loading all rows at once isn't possible, e.g the dataset is too large.

By passing in a function to @loadData you assume the responsibility to filter, sort and paginate the data (if said features are enabled).

This function must return an array or a promise that resolves with an array.

This function will be called with an argument with the current state of the table. Use this object to know what data to fetch, pass it to the server, etc. Please check the "Async Data" guide to understand what that object contains and an example of its usage.

arguments.name: pagination
arguments.description: Use this argument to enable the pagination feature. Default is false.

arguments.name: pageSize
arguments.description: Controls the size of each page. Default is 15.

arguments.name: pageNumber
arguments.description: Controls the current page to show. Default is 1.

arguments.name: totalRows
arguments.description: Optional argument that informs yeti table of how many rows your data has. Only needed when using a @loadData function and @pagination={{true}}. When you use @data, Yeti Table uses the size of that array. This information is used to calculate the pagination information that is yielded and passed to the @loadData function.

arguments.name: filter
arguments.description: The global filter. If passed in, Yeti Table will search all the rows that contain this string and show them. Defaults to ''.

arguments.name: filterFunction
arguments.description:
An optional function to customize the filtering logic. This function should return true or false to either include or exclude the row on the resulting set. If this function depends on a value, pass that value as the @filterUsing argument.

This function will be called with two arguments:

  • row - the current data row to use for filtering
  • filterUsing - the value you passed in as @filterUsing

arguments.name: filterUsing
arguments.description: If you @filterFunction function depends on a different value (other that @filter) to show, pass it in this argument. Yeti Table uses this argument to know when to recalculate the fitlered rows.

arguments.name: sortable
arguments.description: Used to enable/disable sorting on all columns. You should use this to avoid passing the @sortable argument to all columns.

arguments.name: sortFunction
arguments.description: Use the @sortFunction if you want to completely customize how the row sorting is done. It will be invoked with two rows, the current sortings that are applied and the @compareFunction.

arguments.name: compareFunction
arguments.description: Use @compareFunction if you just want to customize how two values relate to each other (not the entire row). It will be invoked with two values and you just need to return -1, 0 or 1 depending on if first value is greater than the second or not. The default compare function used is the compare function from @ember/utils.

arguments.name: sortSequence
arguments.description: Use @sortSequence to customize the sequence in which the sorting order will cycle when clicking on the table headers. You can either pass in a comma-separated string or an array of strings. Accepted values are 'asc', 'desc' and 'unsorted'. The default value is ['asc', 'desc'].

yields.name: table.actions
yields.description: an object that contains actions to interact with the table

yields.name: table.paginationData
yields.description: object that represents the current pagination state

yields.name: table.isLoading
yields.description: boolean that is `true` when data is being loaded

yields.name: table.totalColumns
yields.description: the number of visible columns on the table

attributes.name: Column
attributes.description:
An important component yielded from the header component that is used to define a column of the table.

<header.column @prop="firstName" as |column|>
  First name
  {{if column.isAscSorted "(sorted asc)"}}
  {{if column.isDescSorted "(sorted desc)"}}
</header.column>

arguments.name: prop
arguments.description:
An important argument that Yeti Table uses to tiw this column to a certain property on each row object of the original @data (or @loadFunction) that was passed in.

This is the argument that allows Yeti Table to keep itself up to date when the original data changes.

If you don't need sorting, filtering or automatic table unrolling (using the blockless body component), then this property is optional.

arguments.name: visible
arguments.description: Set to false to hide the entire column across all rows. Keep in mind that this property won't just hide the column using css. The DOM for the column will be removed. Defaults to true.

arguments.name: sortable
arguments.description: Used to turn off sorting clicking on this column (clicks won't toggle sorting anymore). Useful on avatar columns, for example, where a sorting order doesn't really make sense. Defaults to the <YetiTable> @sortable argument (which in turn defaults to true).

arguments.name: sort
arguments.description: Optionally use an asc or desc string on this argument to turn on ascending or descending sorting on this column. Useful to turn on default sortings on the table.

arguments.name: sortSequence
arguments.description: Use @sortSequence to customize the sequence in which the sorting order will cycle when clicking on this column header. You can either pass in a comma-separated string or an array of strings. Accepted values are 'asc', 'desc' and 'unsorted'. The default value is ['asc', 'desc'] or whatever the global table sortSequence value is.

arguments.name: filterable
arguments.description: Used to turn off filtering for this column. When false, Yeti Table won't look for values on this column. Defaults to true.

arguments.name: filter
arguments.description:
The column filter. If passed in, Yeti Table will search this column for rows that contain this string and show those rows.

The column definitions @filter argument is subtractive, meaning that it will filter out rows from the subset that passes the general @filter.

arguments.name: filterFunction
arguments.description:
An optional function to customize the filtering logic on this column. This function should return true or false to either include or exclude the row on the resulting set. If this function depends on a value, pass that value as the @filterUsing argument.

This function will be called with two arguments:

  • value - the current data cell to use for filtering
  • filterUsing - the value you passed in as @filterUsing

arguments.name: filterUsing
arguments.description: If you @filterFunction function depends on a different value (other that @filter) to show, pass it in this argument. Yeti Table uses this argument to know when to recalculate the fitlered rows.

arguments.name: columnClass
arguments.description: Used to add a class to all the cells in this column.

yields.name: column.isSorted
yields.description: `true` if column is sorted ascending or descending

attributes.name: Header
attributes.description:
Renders a <thead> element and yields the column component.

<table.header as |header|>
  <header.column @prop="firstName">
    First name
  </header.column>
  <header.column @prop="lastName">
    Last name
  </header.column>
  <header.column @prop="points">
    Points
  </header.column>
</table.header>

attributes.name: Pagination
attributes.description:
Simple pagination controls component that is included to help you get started quickly. Yeti Table yields a lot of pagination data, so you shouldn't have a problem creating your own pagination controls.

At any rate, this component tries to be as flexible as possible. Some arguments are provided to customize how this component behaves.

If you want to render these controls on the table footer, you probably want a footer row that always spans all rows. To do that you can use a colspan equal to the yielded totalColumns number. Example:

<tfoot>
  <tr>
    <td colspan={{table.totalColumns}}>
      <table.pagination/>
    </td>
  </tr>
</tfoot>

arguments.name: pageSizes
arguments.description: Array of page sizes to populate the page size <select>. Particularly useful with an array helper, e.g @pageSizes={{array 10 12 23 50 100}} Defaults to [10, 15, 20, 25].

arguments.name: showInfo
arguments.description: Used to show/hide some textual information about the current page. Defaults to true.

arguments.name: showPageSizeSelector
arguments.description: Used to show/hide the page size selector. Defaults to true.

arguments.name: showButtons
arguments.description: Used to show/hide the previous and next page buttons. Defaults to true.
